CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Not necessary to examine Art. 14+8;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - domestic and Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in PERSON . They have a son , born on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The parents chose the name “ PERSON ” for their son . On DATE ORG ( maistraatti , magistraten ) refused the applicants ' application to register this forename under section CARDINALb , subsections CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , of LAW ( nimilaki , namnlagen – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) as this form of spelling did not comply with NORP naming practice .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to the then ORG ( lääninoikeus , länsrätten , later replaced by ORG ( hallinto - oikeus , förvaltningsdomstolen ) ) . They argued that the name “ PERSON ” was common in GPE and GPE , and it was also used in GPE and GPE . It was pronounceable in the NORP language and was not incompatible with NORP naming practice . There were CARDINAL persons with that name registered in ORG ( väestötietojärjestelmä , befolkningsdatasystemet ) of GPE . Furthermore , they might move abroad later .

CARDINAL . The ORG representative appointed by ORG ( lääninhallituksen määräämä asiamies , ombudsman förordnad av länssyrelsen ) was invited to submit an opinion to ORG . In his opinion , the name should have been accepted for registration since owing to increasing international contacts and cooperation , registration of a name could not be refused on the sole basis that it was contrary to domestic naming practice .

CARDINAL . In its submissions to the court ORG on Names ( nimilautakunta , nämnden för namnärenden ) considered that the proposed name was incompatible with NORP naming practice and that the applicants had not adduced adequate reasons for choosing it .

CARDINAL . NORP In response to these observations , the applicants maintained that they should be allowed to name their son “ PERSON ” as ORG had registered various other forenames , such as “ PERSON ” , “ NORP ” , “ GPE ” and “ NORP ” , which , in the applicants ' view , were modified forenames and contrary to NORP naming practice in these forms .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed their appeal on DATE . The court referred to LAW , by which a name could be accepted , even if incompatible with domestic naming practice , where a person had a connection with a foreign State on the basis of nationality , family relations or some other special circumstance and the proposed forename accorded with the naming practice of that ORG . The name could also be accepted for other valid reasons ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The court concluded that the arguments submitted by the applicants were insufficient to allow the forename to be registered .

CARDINAL . In their application to ORG ( korkein hallinto - oikeus , högsta förvaltningsdomstolen ) the applicants claimed that it was open to interpretation whether the name “ PERSON ” was contrary to LAW . They contended that some priests and population registration authorities would have accepted the name . Furthermore , CARDINAL NORP persons already had that name . In their view the name “ PERSON ” should have been accepted for their son because it had been accepted for other persons . The name fulfilled the criteria of LAW in that it was clearly a male name and could not cause any harm to their son . Further , they had used the name in family circles .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the decision .

CARDINAL . LAW No . DATE , as amended by LAW . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , contains provisions on names . Under section CARDINALa , a child has to be given CARDINAL forenames upon his or her birth . The chosen name must be declared to ORG or the church for registration .

CARDINAL . NORP legislation does not contain any provisions as to how a forename has to be chosen . There exist , however , almanacs on NORP , NORP , PERSON and NORP names , outlining domestic naming practice . A forename which is not mentioned in an almanac may also be accepted for registration if there are no general obstacles to permitting it under section CARDINALb of LAW , subsections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of which read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . In the absence of a reason mentioned in subsection CARDINAL the following categories of names can not be accepted for a forename :
( CARDINAL ) a name which by virtue of its form or spelling is incompatible with domestic naming practice ;
( CARDINAL ) a female name for a boy and a male name for a girl ;
( CARDINAL ) a surname ... ;
( CARDINAL ) a name if it has already been given to a person 's sibling .
CARDINAL . A forename which does not comply with the requirements in subsection CARDINAL may , however , be permitted :
( CARDINAL ) on the grounds of a religious tradition ;

( CARDINAL ) if a person , on the basis of nationality , family relations or some other special circumstance , has a connection with a foreign ORG and the proposed forename accords with the practice of the said ORG ; or
( CARDINAL ) if some other valid reason is considered to exist . ”

CARDINAL . ORG on Names , subordinate to ORG , gives advisory opinions to the authorities and courts on the application of LAW . It also monitors domestic naming practice and proposes legislative amendments .
